description: Apples are one of the most popular fruits worldwide, known for their crisp texture and sweet or tart flavor. They are rich in fiber, vitamin C, and antioxidants. Apple trees can live for decades and produce fruit for many years when properly cared for.
growth_period: 3-5 years to first fruit, 10-15 years to full production
watering_requirements: Deep watering 1-2 times per week, more frequent during dry spells
planting_method: Plant bare-root or container trees in early spring or fall
spacing_requirements: 15-20 feet apart for standard trees, 8-12 feet for dwarf varieties
fertilizer_requirements: Apply balanced fertilizer (10-10-10) in early spring, avoid late season fertilization
disease_prevention: Prune regularly to improve air circulation, remove dead branches, apply dormant oil spray in late winter, monitor for pests and diseases, use disease-resistant varieties when possible
special_care: Protect from frost in spring, thin fruit to improve quality, provide support for young trees, mulch around base to retain moisture

description: Blueberries are small, sweet, and nutrient-dense fruits packed with antioxidants, vitamin C, and fiber. They are known for their brain-boosting properties and anti-inflammatory benefits. Blueberry bushes are perennial and can produce fruit for 20+ years.
growth_period: 2-3 years to first fruit, 5-7 years to full production
soil_requirements: Acidic soil (pH 4.5-5.5), well-drained, rich in organic matter
watering_requirements: Consistent moisture, water when top inch of soil is dry
planting_method: Plant container-grown or bare-root plants in early spring
spacing_requirements: 4-6 feet apart for highbush varieties, 2-3 feet for lowbush
fertilizer_requirements: Use acidic fertilizer (azalea/camellia type) in early spring and after harvest
disease_prevention: Maintain soil acidity with sulfur or peat moss, mulch with pine needles or sawdust, ensure good drainage, avoid overhead watering, prune in late winter to remove old canes
special_care: Protect from birds with netting, maintain consistent soil moisture, avoid excessive nitrogen which can reduce fruit production

description: Cherries are delicious stone fruits available in sweet and sour varieties. They are rich in antioxidants, vitamin C, and melatonin. Cherry trees are beautiful ornamental trees that also produce tasty fruit.
growth_period: 3-5 years to first fruit, 7-10 years to full production
soil_requirements: Well-drained, sandy loam soil with pH 6.0-7.5
watering_requirements: Deep watering weekly, more frequent during dry periods
planting_method: Plant bare-root trees in early spring
fertilizer_requirements: Apply balanced fertilizer in early spring, avoid over-fertilization
disease_prevention: Prune to maintain open canopy, remove diseased branches, apply fungicides preventively, use disease-resistant varieties, monitor for pests like cherry fruit fly
special_care: Protect from birds, harvest when fully ripe, thin fruit clusters for better quality, provide winter protection in cold climates

description: Corn is a staple cereal grain and one of the world's most important crops. It's rich in carbohydrates, fiber, and essential nutrients. Sweet corn is popular for fresh consumption, while field corn is used for animal feed and industrial purposes.
watering_requirements: 1-2 inches of water per week, more during tasseling and silking
planting_method: Plant seeds directly in ground 1-2 inches deep
spacing_requirements: 8-12 inches apart in rows 30-36 inches apart
fertilizer_requirements: Side-dress with nitrogen fertilizer when plants are 12 inches tall and again when tassels appear
disease_prevention: Rotate crops annually, plant in blocks for better pollination, remove weeds regularly, use resistant varieties, monitor for pests and diseases
special_care: Harvest when kernels are plump and milky, check ripeness by piercing a kernel, harvest in the morning when cool

description: Grapes are versatile fruits used for fresh consumption, wine making, and raisins. They are rich in antioxidants, resveratrol, and vitamins. Grapevines are long-lived plants that can produce fruit for 30+ years with proper care.
growth_period: 2-3 years to first fruit, 5-7 years to full production
watering_requirements: Deep watering weekly, reduce watering as fruit matures
planting_method: Plant dormant bare-root vines or container plants
spacing_requirements: 6-8 feet apart in rows 8-10 feet apart
fertilizer_requirements: Apply balanced fertilizer in early spring, avoid excessive nitrogen
disease_prevention: Prune annually in late winter, train vines on trellis, improve air circulation, remove diseased leaves, use disease-resistant varieties, apply fungicides preventively
special_care: Protect from birds, harvest when fully ripe, test sugar content for wine grapes, provide support structure

description: Oranges are citrus fruits known for their high vitamin C content and refreshing flavor. They are excellent sources of antioxidants and fiber. Orange trees are evergreen and can produce fruit for 50+ years in suitable climates.
growth_period: 3-5 years to first fruit, 8-12 years to full production
soil_requirements: Well-drained, sandy loam soil with pH 6.0-7.5
watering_requirements: Deep watering weekly, reduce frequency in winter
temperature_range: 10°C to 35°C (hardy in USDA zones 9-11, protect from frost)
planting_method: Plant container-grown trees in spring or fall
fertilizer_requirements: Apply citrus-specific fertilizer 3-4 times per year
disease_prevention: Protect from frost, monitor for citrus greening disease, apply horticultural oil for pests, ensure good drainage, prune to improve air circulation, remove diseased branches immediately
special_care: Protect from freezing temperatures, provide wind protection, maintain consistent moisture, mulch around base

description: Peaches are juicy stone fruits with fuzzy skin and sweet, aromatic flesh. They are rich in vitamins A and C, fiber, and antioxidants. Peach trees are relatively short-lived but produce abundant fruit when well-maintained.
growth_period: 2-4 years to first fruit, 5-7 years to full production
soil_requirements: Well-drained, sandy loam soil with pH 6.0-7.0
watering_requirements: Deep watering weekly, more frequent during fruit development
planting_method: Plant bare-root or container trees in early spring
fertilizer_requirements: Apply balanced fertilizer in early spring, avoid late season fertilization
disease_prevention: Prune annually in late winter, thin fruit to prevent branch breakage, monitor for peach leaf curl, apply dormant oil spray, use disease-resistant varieties
special_care: Protect from late spring frosts, thin fruit clusters, harvest when fully ripe, provide winter protection in cold climates

description: Bell peppers are mild, sweet peppers available in various colors (green, red, yellow, orange). They are rich in vitamins A and C, antioxidants, and fiber. Bell peppers are warm-season vegetables that produce abundant fruit.
watering_requirements: 1-2 inches of water per week, consistent moisture
temperature_range: 20°C to 30°C (warm season crop, protect from frost)
planting_method: Start seeds indoors 8-10 weeks before last frost, transplant outdoors
spacing_requirements: 18-24 inches apart in rows 24-30 inches apart
fertilizer_requirements: Apply balanced fertilizer at planting and again when first fruits appear
disease_prevention: Rotate crops annually, provide support for heavy fruit, mulch to retain moisture, monitor for pests, use row covers for early season protection
special_care: Harvest green peppers early or wait for color change, cut peppers from plant with stem, continue harvesting to encourage more fruit production

description: Potatoes are starchy tuber vegetables and one of the world's most important food crops. They are rich in carbohydrates, vitamin C, and potassium. Potatoes are versatile and can be stored for long periods.
growing_season: Spring (2-3 weeks before last frost, March-May)
soil_requirements: Well-drained, loose, sandy soil with pH 5.0-6.0
watering_requirements: 1-2 inches of water per week, consistent moisture
planting_method: Plant seed potatoes (cut pieces with eyes) 4-6 inches deep
spacing_requirements: 12-15 inches apart in rows 30-36 inches apart
fertilizer_requirements: Apply low-nitrogen fertilizer at planting, avoid excessive nitrogen
disease_prevention: Rotate crops annually, hill soil around plants as they grow, remove weeds carefully, use certified disease-free seed potatoes, monitor for late blight
special_care: Harvest when plants die back, cure potatoes in dark, cool place for 2 weeks before storage, store in cool, dark, dry location

description: Raspberries are delicate, sweet berries rich in antioxidants, vitamin C, and fiber. They come in red, black, and yellow varieties. Raspberry canes are perennial and can produce fruit for 10+ years with proper care.
growth_period: 1-2 years to first fruit, 3-4 years to full production
watering_requirements: 1-2 inches of water per week, consistent moisture
planting_method: Plant bare-root or container plants in early spring
spacing_requirements: 2-3 feet apart in rows 6-8 feet apart
fertilizer_requirements: Apply balanced fertilizer in early spring, avoid excessive nitrogen
disease_prevention: Prune annually to remove old canes, provide trellis support, mulch to retain moisture, monitor for pests, use disease-resistant varieties
harvest_time: Early to mid-summer (June-August) for summer-bearing, fall for everbearing
special_care: Protect from birds with netting, harvest when fully ripe, prune after harvest, provide winter protection in cold climates

description: Soybeans are legumes rich in protein, fiber, and essential amino acids. They are used for food, animal feed, and industrial purposes. Soybeans are important for soil health as they fix nitrogen.
watering_requirements: 1-2 inches of water per week, more during pod development
planting_method: Plant seeds directly in ground 1-2 inches deep
spacing_requirements: 2-4 inches apart in rows 24-30 inches apart
fertilizer_requirements: Inoculate seeds with nitrogen-fixing bacteria, apply phosphorus fertilizer if needed
disease_prevention: Rotate crops annually, inoculate seeds with rhizobia bacteria, monitor for pests, use disease-resistant varieties, avoid planting in same area consecutively
special_care: Harvest when pods are dry and brown, allow plants to dry before harvesting, thresh to remove beans from pods

description: Squash includes summer squash (zucchini, yellow squash) and winter squash (pumpkin, butternut). They are rich in vitamins A and C, fiber, and antioxidants. Squash plants are prolific producers in warm weather.
watering_requirements: 1-2 inches of water per week, consistent moisture
temperature_range: 20°C to 30°C (warm season crop, protect from frost)
planting_method: Start seeds indoors 3-4 weeks before last frost or direct sow
spacing_requirements: 24-36 inches apart in rows 4-6 feet apart
fertilizer_requirements: Apply balanced fertilizer at planting and again when vines start to run
disease_prevention: Rotate crops annually, provide adequate spacing, mulch to retain moisture, monitor for squash bugs and vine borers, hand-pollinate if needed
harvest_time: Summer squash: 50-70 days, Winter squash: 80-120 days
special_care: Harvest summer squash when small and tender, harvest winter squash when skin is hard, cure winter squash before storage

description: Strawberries are sweet, aromatic berries rich in vitamin C, antioxidants, and fiber. They are one of the most popular garden fruits. Strawberry plants are perennial and can produce fruit for 3-5 years.
growth_period: First year: light crop, Second year: full production
watering_requirements: 1-2 inches of water per week, consistent moisture
planting_method: Plant bare-root or container plants in early spring or fall
spacing_requirements: 12-18 inches apart in rows 3-4 feet apart
fertilizer_requirements: Apply balanced fertilizer in early spring and after harvest
disease_prevention: Mulch with straw to keep fruit clean, remove runners to focus energy on fruit, monitor for pests and diseases, use disease-resistant varieties, provide winter protection
special_care: Protect from birds with netting, harvest when fully ripe, remove old leaves after harvest, renovate beds annually

description: Tomatoes are one of the most popular garden vegetables (technically fruits). They are rich in lycopene, vitamin C, and antioxidants. Tomatoes come in many varieties and are versatile in cooking.
growth_period: 60-90 days from transplanting depending on variety
watering_requirements: 1-2 inches of water per week, consistent moisture, avoid overhead watering
temperature_range: 20°C to 30°C (warm season crop, protect from frost)
planting_method: Start seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before last frost, transplant outdoors
spacing_requirements: 18-36 inches apart depending on variety, rows 3-4 feet apart
fertilizer_requirements: Apply balanced fertilizer at planting and again when first fruits appear
disease_prevention: Rotate crops annually, provide support (stakes or cages), prune indeterminate varieties, mulch to retain moisture, monitor for pests and diseases, use disease-resistant varieties
special_care: Harvest when fully ripe, continue harvesting to encourage more fruit, protect from extreme heat, provide adequate support
